header_1: H5N1 in Wild Birds in Hong Kong:
content_1: A bird, possibly a red-billed starling (Sturnus  sericeus), has tested positive for H5N1.  The dead bird was found on  May 26 in the densely populated section of Mong Kok, Kowloon, China and is  undergoing further tests to determine the neuraminidase subtype and  pathogenicity.  A total of 15 wild birds have tested positive for H5N1 in  China so far in 2007.
header_2: H5N1 in Wild Birds in Russia:
content_2: Antibodies to, or genetic material of, H5 avian influenza  has been detected in 41 samples from wild migrant birds collected in Russia.  Antibodies to H5 or H7 were also detected in 19 samples from wild migrant birds  collected in three districts of the Tomsk Region. It is unclear if any of the  avian influenza viruses detected are highly pathogenic or are the low  pathogenic types commonly found in wild birds.  A total of 1,500 birds  were tested during the monitoring program.
header_3: H5N1 in Wild Birds in United Arab Emirates:
content_3: This week the UAE government reported  that 62,155 wild birds belonging to 125 species and 42 families have been  tested during the spring migration ending in March 2007, and no cases of avian  influenza have been found. (more...)
